<|ref|>title<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 123, 637, 146]]<|/det|> # Cambridge International AS & A Level <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 172, 195, 185]]<|/det|> CANDIDATE NAME <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 220, 163, 235]]<|/det|> CENTRE NUMBER <|ref|>table<|/ref|><|det|>[[212, 213, 424, 261]]<|/det|>
<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[724, 220, 722, 235]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[867, 220, 866, 235]]<|/det|> <|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[736, 213, 756, 241]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[891, 220, 898, 241]]<|/det|> <|ref|>title<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 279, 179, 294]]<|/det|> # PHYSICS <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[827, 279, 906, 294]]<|/det|> 9702/52 <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 302, 413, 317]]<|/det|> Paper 5 Planning, Analysis and Evaluation <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[759, 305, 907, 321]]<|/det|> May/June 2025 <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[757, 328, 907, 343]]<|/det|> 1 hour 15 minutes <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[93, 355, 399, 372]]<|/det|> You must answer on the question paper. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[93, 384, 362, 399]]<|/det|> No additional materials are needed. <|ref|>title<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 418, 225, 432]]<|/det|> # INSTRUCTIONS <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[93, 435, 294, 450]]<|/det|> - Answer all questions. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 449, 764, 467]]<|/det|> - Use a black or dark blue pen. You may use an HB pencil for any diagrams or graphs. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 462, 808, 479]]<|/det|> - Write your name, centre number and candidate number in the boxes at the top of the page. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 480, 565, 497]]<|/det|> - Write your answer to each question in the space provided. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 497, 482, 512]]<|/det|> - Do not use an erasable pen or correction fluid. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 513, 363, 528]]<|/det|> - Do not write on any bar codes. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 528, 330, 545]]<|/det|> - You may use a calculator. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 542, 579, 559]]<|/det|> - You should show all your working and use appropriate units. <|ref|>title<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 589, 217, 602]]<|/det|> # INFORMATION <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 605, 388, 620]]<|/det|> - The total mark for this paper is 30. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 620, 730, 637]]<|/det|> - The number of marks for each question or part question is shown in brackets [ ] .

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[81, 74, 918, 91]]<|/det|>
1 A thin solid disc of radius \(r\) and thickness \(z\) is attached to a thin axle. String is wrapped around the axle, as shown in Fig. 1.1.

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[220, 117, 780, 384]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[466, 404, 532, 421]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 435, 474, 452]]<|/det|>
A block of mass \(m\) is attached to the string.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 466, 918, 481]]<|/det|>
The block is released from rest and falls downwards. The block has speed \(v\) when it has fallen through a distance \(h\) from the point of release. The value of \(v\) is determined using one light gate

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 497, 294, 512]]<|/det|>
connected to a timer.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 526, 570, 544]]<|/det|>
It is suggested that \(v\) is related to \(m\) by the relationship

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[425, 554, 576, 587]]<|/det|>
\[
\frac{h}{v^{2}}=\frac{\pi r^{2} z}{2 P Q m}+\frac{1}{P}
\]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 593, 366, 608]]<|/det|>
where \(P\) and \(Q\) are constants.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 624, 695, 641]]<|/det|>
Plan a laboratory experiment to test the relationship between \(v\) and \(m\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 655, 625, 672]]<|/det|>
Draw a diagram showing the arrangement of your equipment.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 685, 703, 703]]<|/det|>
Explain how the results could be used to determine values for \(P\) and \(Q\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 716, 382, 733]]<|/det|>
In your plan you should include:

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 747, 393, 764]]<|/det|>
- the procedure to be followed

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 776, 410, 791]]<|/det|>
- the measurements to be taken

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 806, 347, 821]]<|/det|>
- the control of variables

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 833, 352, 852]]<|/det|>
- the analysis of the data

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 862, 446, 879]]<|/det|>
- any safety precautions to be taken.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[80, 74, 921, 91]]<|/det|>
2 A student investigates a circuit containing capacitors. The circuit is connected with a capacitor of capacitance \(A\), as shown in Fig. 2.1.

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[370, 118, 627, 423]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[466, 441, 532, 458]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 472, 802, 488]]<|/det|>
Two capacitors, each of capacitance \(C\), are connected in parallel between P and Q .

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 503, 634, 518]]<|/det|>
Initially, switch X and switch Z are closed and switch Y is open.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 533, 918, 549]]<|/det|>
Switches X and Z are opened. Switch Y is then closed. The maximum potential difference between P and Q is measured using the voltmeter. This procedure is repeated and the mean maximum

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 564, 565, 581]]<|/det|>
potential difference \(V\) between \(P\) and \(Q\) is determined.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 595, 918, 612]]<|/det|>
The experiment is then repeated by changing the number \(n\) of capacitors, each of capacitance \(C\), connected in parallel between P and Q .

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 642, 570, 657]]<|/det|>
It is suggested that \(V\) and \(n\) are related by the equation

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[433, 673, 565, 688]]<|/det|>
\[
E A=V(n C+A)
\]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 702, 581, 719]]<|/det|>
where \(E\) is the electromotive force (e.m.f.) of the battery.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 731, 659, 761]]<|/det|>
(a) A graph is plotted of \(\frac{1}{V}\) on the \(y\)-axis against \(n\) on the \(x\)-axis.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[157, 769, 611, 785]]<|/det|>
Determine expressions for the gradient and \(y\)-intercept.

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[472, 875, 590, 926]]<|/det|>
\[
\begin{array}{r}
\text { gradient }= \\
y \text {-intercept }=
\end{array}
\]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 74, 918, 92]]<|/det|> (b) Values of \(n\) and the two measured values of the maximum potential difference \(V_{1}\) and \(V_{2}\) are given in Table 2.1. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[458, 121, 540, 136]]<|/det|> <|ref|>table<|/ref|><|det|>[[156, 151, 843, 462]]<|/det|>
\(n\)

Include the absolute uncertainties <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[157, 505, 264, 536]]<|/det|> in \(V\) and \(\frac{1}{V}\). <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 540, 682, 571]]<|/det|> (c) (i) Plot a graph of \(\frac{1}{V} / \mathrm{V}^{-1}\) against \(n\). Include error bars for \(\frac{1}{V}\). <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 577, 918, 594]]<|/det|> (ii) Draw the straight line of best fit and a worst acceptable straight line on your graph. Label both lines. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 624, 918, 641]]<|/det|> (iii) Determine the gradient of the line of best fit. Include the absolute uncertainty in your answer.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 74, 918, 91]]<|/det|>
(iv) Determine the \(y\)-intercept of the line of best fit. Include the absolute uncertainty in your answer.

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[477, 213, 587, 230]]<|/det|>
\[
y \text {-intercept = }
\]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 244, 918, 261]]<|/det|>
(d) (i) Using your answers to (a), (c)(iii) and (c)(iv), determine the values of \(E\) and \(C\). Include appropriate units.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[196, 290, 395, 307]]<|/det|>
Data: \(A=(2.2 \pm 0.2) \mathrm{mF}\)

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[549, 472, 590, 524]]<|/det|>
\[
\begin{aligned}
& E= \\
& C=
\end{aligned}
\]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 552, 661, 569]]<|/det|>
(ii) Determine the percentage uncertainty in your value of \(C\).

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[375, 675, 587, 693]]<|/det|>
\[percentage uncertainty =\]

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[867, 675, 892, 692]]<|/det|>
\[
\%
\]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[894, 676, 919, 693]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 706, 918, 723]]<|/det|>
(e) The experiment is repeated with 10 capacitors, each of capacitance \(C\), connected in parallel between P and Q . Determine the maximum potential difference \(V\) between P and Q .

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[552, 849, 591, 866]]<|/det|>
